courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Introduction to Mental Health and Related Issues
courses.description: The introductory module will discuss the basic knowledge of mental health and related issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Appreciation of the fundamentals in psychopathology and application of diagnostic criteria; 2) Understand the theoretical basis for adopting multidisciplinary approach in psychiatric assessment and management; 3) Understand the application of mental health ordinance in management of severe mental disorders and developing community psychiatric service; 4) Basic understanding of the role of psychiatric assessment in criminal and civil legal situations.
courses.course_syllabus: The introductory module will discuss the basic knowledge of mental health and related issues. Students will be expected to gain an understanding of the principles underlying assessment and management in modern mental health science and the clinical applications. Topics to be covered include “History and development of Modern Mental Health Classification Systems”, “Interviewing skills”, “Overview of common mental health problems in special groups- Old Age, Child and Adolescent, Women”, “Community Psychiatry” .
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Psychiatric Interview, The: Practical Guides in Psychiatry by Daniel J Carlat. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; Second Edition edition (September 1, 2004)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Common Mental Health Problems and its Management
courses.description: This module continues to explore mental health in theoretical and practical settings.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Indepth understanding of the specific and general management approaches to high-prevalence mental disorders; 2) Appreciation of the scientific bases of special treatment modalities such as ECT, brain stimulation etc for psychiatric disorders; 3) Understanding the effects of comorbidity on individual case management.
courses.course_syllabus: This module continues to explore mental health in theoretical and practical settings. Its overall objective is to provide students with a more in-depth understanding of mental health care. Clinical knowledge and skills of different mental illnesses will be covered. By the end of the module, students should have developed the basic skills needed to manage patients in an integrated and coordinated manner. (e.g. Stress related disorders, Anxiety disorders, Mood disorders, Sleep disorders, Eating disorders, Sexual disorders, Somatoform disorders, Substance abuse including alcoholism, Psychotic disorders, Post-partum mood disorders, Personality disorders). Special physical treatment modalities such as Electroconvulsive Therapy, Brain stimulation and Psychosurgery will be covered under relevant disease topics.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Oxford Core texts: Psychiatry

Gelder M., Mayou R. and Geddes J., Oxford; New York: Oxford University Press, 2005 (3rd Edition).

2. Psychiatry in Medical Practice

Goldberg D., Benjamin S. and Creed F., London; New York: Routledge, 1994 (2nd Edition).

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Basic Psychopharmacology
courses.description: This module will provide students with a solid grounding in psychopharmacotherapy, as applied to mental health care.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Understanding the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of common psychotropic drugs. 2) Application of knowledge in pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics in the appreciation of efficacy and tolerability profile; 3) Basic techniques in risk-benefit analysis when considering indication and contraindication of individual pharmacological agents.
courses.course_syllabus: This module will provide students with a solid grounding in psychopharmacotherapy, as applied to mental health care. Through understanding of the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of major categories of psychotropic drugs commonly used in modern clinical practice, students should be able to appreciate the scientific basis of the efficacy and tolerability profiles of pharmacological agents. Students are also guided to develop a critical appraisal approach to the evidence basis for the commonly used pharmacological treatment algorithm
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Principles and Practice of Psychopharmacotherapy by Janicak P.G. et al., Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2001 (3rd Edition).

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Fundamentals of Psychotherapeutic Interventions
courses.description: This module will provide students with a solid grounding in psychological intervention, as applied to mental health care.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Understanding the important of therapeutic alliance, maintaining boundaries, ethics in psychotherapy; 2) Basic understanding of the theorectical constructs of commom schools of psychotherapy; 3) Appreciation of the complementaty roles of Psychotherapy in psychiatric case management; 4)Appreciation of the evidence-based efficacy of some common psychotherapeutic approaches
courses.course_syllabus: This module will provide students with a solid grounding in psychological intervention, as applied to mental health care. The historical perspectives, theoretical basis, therapeutic process and practical applications of some commonly known psychotherapeutic approaches including Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Psychoanalysis, Hypnosis, Group Therapy & Counseling will be discussed
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Clinicians: Psychotherapy in Clinical Practice by Donna M Sudak. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 1 edition (February 2, 2006)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Clinical Supervision and Practice 1
courses.description: This module requires work related exposure to settings involving care of persons with mental health problems or mental disorders, in a medical (including nursing and allied health disciplines) or social setting.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1)Identification of key psychiatric diagnoses; 2)Formulation of biopsychosocial aetiological model; 3)Risk assessment; 4) Formulation of problem list; 5) Formulation of individual service planning
courses.course_syllabus: This module requires work or work attachment involving care of persons with mental health problems or mental disorders, in a medical (including nursing and allied health disciplines) or social setting. In each module, student must write 3 case reports (1000-2000 words) with case discussion with clinical supervisors assigned by the course directors.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Kaplan & Sadock's Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry by Harold I Kaplan. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins (2004)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Clinical Supervision and Practice 2
courses.description: This module requires work related exposure to settings involving care of persons with mental health problems or mental disorders, in a medical (including nursing and allied health disciplines) or social setting.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Application of community-oriented approach to case-management; 2) Development of sensitivity to family needs; 3) Application of psychotherapeutic techniques; 4) Formulation of prognostication of chronic mental illness; 5) Mastery of skills in evaluating clinical outcomes
courses.course_syllabus: This module requires work or work attachment involving care of persons with mental health problems or mental disorders, in a medical (including nursing and allied health disciplines) or social setting. In each module, student must write 3 case reports (1000-2000 words) with case discussion with clinical supervisors assigned by the course directors.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Kaplan & Sadock's Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry by Harold I Kaplan. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins (2004)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Severe Mental Disorders&Risk Ass
courses.description: This module aims to equip students with an in-depth understanding of the multidisciplinary approach to the care for severe mental disorders.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Understanding of the neurobiological and genetic basis of severe mental illness; 2) Appreciation of the short-term and long-term risk, morbidity and mortality of severe mental illness; 3) Understanding of the illness trajectory under mental health ordinance; 4) Understanding the community-tertiary care interfacing in the identification and management of severe mental illness
courses.course_syllabus: This module aims to equip students with an in-depth understanding of the multidisciplinary approach to the care for severe mental disorders ranging from Schizophrenic Spectrum Disorder, Bipolar Affective Disorder, Organic Psychotic/ Mood Disorder, Substance-related Mental and Behavioral Disorders and Personality Disorders. Students are guided to develop a systematic approach to identification and assessment of suicide risks and risk of violence related to severe mental disorders as well as common mental disorders across a wide-range of clinical settings, i.e. primary care level, forensic psychiatric setting, non-psychiatric tertiary care facilities and consultation-liaison setting.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Kaplan & Sadock's Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry by Harold I Kaplan. LIPPINCOTT WILLIAMS AND WILKINS (2004)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Old Age Psychiatry
courses.description: This module will equip students with basic knowledge and understanding concerning common mental health problems in late life.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Use of common bedside cognitive and functional assessments; 2) Application of community-oriented case management approach to late-life psychiatric problems; 3) Understanding the biopsychosocial aetiologies of late-life mental disorders; 4) Risk assessments in elderly; 5) Application of mental health ordinance in mental health care for elders.
courses.course_syllabus: This module will equip students with basic knowledge and understanding concerning common mental health problems in late life. Assessment and management skills for mild cognitive impairment, dementia, delirium, depression, and adjustment problems will be introduced. Fundamentals of pharmacological and non-pharmacological intervention in the context of multi-disciplinary service models will be emphasized. Students will also be briefed on special issues related to care of older persons with mental health problems, such as mental capacity, guardianship, acute confusional states and cognitive assessment. Students should gain a broad understanding of late onset mental health problems, would be able to identify at-risk conditions, and offer fundamental mental health care for elders in need.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Psychiatry in the Elderly by Robin Jacoby, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 3 edition (April 4, 2002)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Child & Adolescent Psychiatric Problems
courses.description: This module aims to equip students with the knowledge and understanding of issues pertaining to children’s mental health.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Understanding of the normal emotional, social and cognitive developments of children and adolescents; 2) Ability to appreciate how family and immediate social environment affect internalizing and externalizing disorders in children; 3) Understanding the epidemiologic profiles of common psychiatric disorders in childhood; 4) Understanding the special features of severe mental illness (psychosis and affective disorders) in childhood or adolescent-onset cases; 5) Development of sensitivity to childhood physical, emotional or sexual abuse in assessment; 6) Abillity to make biopsychosocial formulation of clinical cases.
courses.course_syllabus: This module aims to equip students with the knowledge and understanding of issues pertaining to children’s mental health. A developmental perspective and multidisciplinary approach will be introduced. The assessment and management of common disorders ranging from neurodevelopmental problems, internalizing problems, and externalizing problems will be covered. At the end of the module, students should have developed the basic skills in the identification of child and adolescent mental health problems, and be aware of the appropriate intervention strategies and services available.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. New Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry by Michael G. Gelder, et al. Oxford University Press, USA; 1 edition (September 4, 2003)

2. Lewis' Child & Adolescent Psychiatry: A Comprehensive Textbook by Andres Martin, et al. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 4th edition (May 1, 2007)

3. Child and Adolescent Psychiatry: A Practical Guide by Dorothy Stubbe. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins (January 1, 2007)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Introduction to Research Methodology
courses.description: The introductory module will discuss the basic knowledge of research methodology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PgDip or MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1)Ability to formulate research questions with succinct foci and objectives; 2)Basic understanding of critical appraisal of scientific publications; 3)Mastery of approaches to browsing electronic databases for scientific literatures; 4)Basic understanding of application of research methodologies (sampling, measurements, statistical analyses and model-building, making statistical and practical inferences; 5) Consideration of research ethics in study design and conduction of fieldwork
courses.course_syllabus: The introductory module will discuss the basic knowledge of research methodology. Students will be expected to gain an understanding of the principles to design and conduct research. Topics to be covered include “Formulation of research questions ", "Critical appraisal of scientific publications", "Utilization of electronic databases for scientific literatures", "Application of research methodologies ( sampling, measuresments, statistical analyses and model-building, making statistical and practical inferences" and "Research ethics".
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Revised course questionnaire will be administered among students every time the course is run.

Reflection of teachers including evidence from assessment will be collected.

Qualitative feedback will be collected from student panels.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Critical appraisal of medical literature. David Marchevsky. Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers, New York. 2000.

2. Biostatistics : a guide to design, analysis, and discovery. Ronald N. Forthofer, Eun Sul Lee, Mike Hernandez. Elsevier Academic Press. 2007.(2nd Edition)

3. Biostatistics : a foundation for analysis in the health sciences. Wayne W. Daniel. John Wiley & Sons. 2009. (9th edition)

4. Biostatistics and epidemiology : a primer for health and biomedical professionals. Sylvia Wassertheil-Smoller. Springer-Verlag. 2004. (3rd edition)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Research Project I
courses.description: During the two year period of the MSc course, students will carry out a research project in the field of mental health studies under the supervision of a supervisor assigned by the course directors. Each student will spend a minimum of four contact hour per week with the supervisor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Students should be able to formulate a research proposal; 2) Ability to plan logistics for fieldwork of the research project.

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Research Project II
courses.description: During the two year period of the MSC course, students will carry out a research project under supervision.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mental Health
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Acquire skills in coordinating and conducting fieldwork of research projects; 2) Acquire skills in data-management and analysis; 3) Ability to synthesize a coherent and logical research dissertation.
courses.course_syllabus: During the two year period of the MSC course, students will carry out a research project in the field of mental health studies under the supervision of a supervisor assigned by the course directors. Each student will spend a minimum of four contact hours per week with the supervisor.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Medical Epidemiology by Raymond Greenberg, et al. McGraw-Hill Medical; 4 edition (October 22, 2004)

2. Clinical Epidemiology: How to Do Clinical Practice Research by David L Sackett, et al. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins (January 1, 2006)

courses.subject: MHLS
courses.title: Evidence-based practice for common mental disorder across lifespan in primary care: a case-based
courses.description: Students will be given diagnosis, assessment and management principles of a selected common mental health problem using case-based discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mental Health or PgD Mental Health
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course Evaluation will be provided at the end of the course
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Biological Psychiatry (Third Edition)- Michael R Trimble, Mark S George (Wiley-Blackwell)

2. DSM-V Pocket Guide for Child and Adolescent Mental Health- Robert J Hilt, Abraham M Nussbaum (American Psychiatric Association Publishing)

3. Clinical manual of Alzheimer Disease and other dementias- Myron F Weiner, Anne M Lipton( American Psychiatric Association Publishing)

4. The Oxford Handbook of Memory- Endel Tulving, Fergus IM Craik (Oxford University Press)

5. Clinical Manual of Child and Adolescent Psychopharmacology (Third Edition)- Molly McVoy, Robert L Finding (American Psychiatric Association Publishing)

6. Learning cognitive-behavior therapy – an illustrated guide (Second Edition)- Jesse H Wright, Gregory K Brown, Michael E Thse, Monica Ramirez Basco (American Psychiatric Association Publishing)

7. Cognitive behavior therapy for psychiatric problems- a practical guide- Keith Hawton, Paul M Salkovskis, Joan Kirk, David M Clark. (Oxford Medical Publications)
